article.description:
Julius Page, critical of his teammates after
several unimpressive outings, scored 16 points and got 
Pittsburgh (No. 4 ESPN/USA Today, No. 5 AP) going with several acrobatic dunks in a 96-51 rout of Norfolk State on Tuesday night.
article.headline: Page scores 16 game after criticizing teammates
article.linkText: Pittsburgh picks it up in blowout of Norfolk State
article.story:
PITTSBURGH (AP) -- Julius Page's shooting was a key to
Pittsburgh's best game this season. His talking might have been
just as important.

	   Page, critical of his teammates after several unimpressive
outings, scored 16 points and got the Panthers (No. 4 ESPN/USA Today, No. 5 AP) going
with several acrobatic dunks in a 96-51 rout of Norfolk State on
Tuesday night.

	   Ontario Lett converted three three-point plays in a span of
three minutes as Pitt (4-0) opened first-half leads of as many as
39 points in easily its most impressive performance.

	   After Pitt struggled for 25 minutes before putting away
Arkansas-Pine Bluff on Saturday, Page said the Panthers didn't
resemble a Top 5 team and should be playing less selfishly and with
more of a team-first attitude.

	   ''Everybody believed in what I said, but maybe the way I said it
was a little out of hand,'' Page said. ''A couple of players took
it a certain way, but I learned ... that what I said should be said
within the team, not out in the open.''

	   Coach Ben Howland must have agreed, holding a team meeting to
caution the players not to be critical of each other in such a
setting.

	   Not surprisingly, Howland downplayed Page's comments, saying,
''We talked about it and it's not a big deal. We're not going to
make a big deal out of it.''

	   Norfolk State (1-2), with only one starter taller than 6-foot-4,
was overwhelmed on the boards for much of the game as Pitt finally
resembled the team that won a school-record 29 games last season.

	   The Panthers dominated from the start, leading by 18 points with
10 minutes gone and shooting 62.3 percent overall. They led by as
many as 50 points, 88-38.

	   ''I didn't expect them to shoot that well,'' Norfolk State coach
Dwight Freeman said. ''They played physical, Big East basketball. I
appreciate Pitt bringing us here because it was a learning
experience.''

	   The Panthers outscored the Spartans 26-5 over the final 9½
minutes of the half to make it 54-15, then spent most of the second
half running a succession of fast breaks that led to dunks or easy
putbacks.

	   ''That's about as well as we can play,'' Howland said. ''It
doesn't matter who we play, if we can come out and play like that,
we're going to beat a lot of people. That was easily the best we've
played. I'm excited about the way we played.''

	   Page backed up his words with 7-of-11 shooting and two
3-pointers. Chevon Troutman added 14 points and Lett and Donatas
Zavackas each scored 13. Pitt limited Norfolk State to 10 rebounds
in the first half before finishing with a 39-26 edge.

	   Lett didn't start for the first time this season, but played his
best game so far with nine rebounds and three blocked shots.

	   ''When Ontario comes off the bench, you can feel him lift the
offense immediately,'' Howland said.

	   Chakowby Hicks scored 10 points for Norfolk State, which split
one-point decisions in its first two games.
